case_name: Income-tax Department v. Hindu undivided family of Gandalal

facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 788 of 1957 filed.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE, JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 788 of 1957. Appeal by special leave from the judgment

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from Bombay High Court judgment dated February 16, 1955 in Income-tax Reference No. 38/x of 1954.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 16, 1955, of the Bombay High Court in Income-tax Reference No. 38/x of 1954.

facts.text: Hindu undivided family of Gandalal carried on cloth business in Wadhwan, Kathiawar, outside British India.

anchor.surface_text: The Hindu undivided family of one Gandalal carried on business in cloth in Wadhwan in Kathiawar, which at the relevant time was outside British India.

facts.text: Family consisted of Gandalal and four sons: Girdharlal, Hansraj, Nandlal, Ramniklal.

anchor.surface_text: The family companysisted of Gandalal and his four sons,  1  Girdharlal,  2  Hansraj,  3  Nandlal and  4  Ramniklal.

facts.text: In 1944 Nandlal came to Bombay and started cloth business in partnership as Amulakh Amichand Co.

anchor.surface_text: In 1944 Nandlal came to Bombay and started a cloth business in partnership with other persons, the partnership being known as Amulakh Amichand Co.

facts.text: Nandlal's share 10 annas, partners' share 6 annas from Amulakh Amichand family.

anchor.surface_text: Nandlals share in the partnership was ten annas and that of his three partners, who belonged to the family of Amulakh Amichand, six annas.

facts.text: Amulakh Amichand family supplied no capital; Nandlal alone financed.

anchor.surface_text: It was stated that the family of Amulakh Amichand which was a well known business family of Bombay, did number supply any capital to the partnership and Nandlal alone was the financing partner.

facts.text: Nandlal received Rs. 50,000 from HUF on April 13, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: On April 13, 1944, Nandlal received a sum of Rs. 50,000 from the Hindu undivided family of which he was a member,

facts.text: Nandlal received further Rs. 50,000 from HUF on April 27, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: and a further sum of Rs. 50,000 on April 27, 1944. Two other sums aggregating to Rs. 50,000 were also received from the Hindu undivided family

facts.text: Two other sums aggregating Rs. 50,000 received from HUF on June 8 and June 29, 1944.

anchor.surface_text: on June 8, 1944, and June 29, 1944. The case of the assessee was that a sum of Rs. 1,00,000 was given to each son by the father

facts.text: Assessee's case: Rs. 1,00,000 gift to each son, June sums loan; Nandlal partner individually.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the assessee was that a sum of Rs. 1,00,000 was given to each son by the father and the sums of money received on June 8, 1944, and June 29, 1944, were a loan by the Hindu undivided family to Nandlal.

facts.text: Department's case: Total Rs. 1,50,000 from HUF used as capital in partnership.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the Department, however, was that the total sum of Rs. 1,50,000 sent to Nandlal by the Hindu undivided family was utilised as capital in the cloth business of the partnership known as Amulakh Amichand Co.

facts.text: Girdharlal joined the firm, given 5 annas share from Nandlal's 10 annas.

anchor.surface_text: Subsequently, Girdharlal, another brother of Nandlal, came to Bombay and joined the firm. Out of the share of ten annas of Nandlal, Girdharlal was given a share of five annas.

facts.text: Partnership started cloth business at Banaras; partners Bombay partners + Banaras outsider.

anchor.surface_text: The partnership firm of Ainulakh Amichand Co. then started a cloth business at Banaras, and the partners of the firm at Banaras were the partners of the Bombay firm of Amulakh Amichand Co. and an outsider from Banaras.

facts.text: Third brother joined Banaras firm without bringing capital.

anchor.surface_text: A third brother of Nandlal also joined the Banaras firm, but he did number bring any capital.

facts.text: For AY 1945-46, ITO held HUF resident in British India, included Rs. 1,50,000 under s.4(1)(b)(iii).

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1945-46 the Income-tax Officer held that the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal was resident in the taxable territories  namely, British India , and hence he included the sum of Rs. 1,50,000

facts.text: Appeal to AAC failed.

anchor.surface_text: The assessee appealed to the Appellate Assistant Commissioner, Bombay, but without success.

facts.text: Tribunal held Nandlal/Girdharlal represented HUF in firms; money from HUF.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal held on the first question that Nandlal and later Girdharlal joined the Bombay firm and also the Banaras firm of Amulakh Amichand Co. as representing the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal

facts.text: Tribunal held HUF not resident in taxable territories for 1945-46; deleted Rs.1,50,000.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, of opinion that for assessment years 1945-46 the Hindu undivided family was number resident in the taxable territories. The actual relief which the Tribunal gave to the assessee was expressed

facts.text: Commissioner requested reference to HC under s.66(1): whether HUF resident.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income- tax, Bombay, who is the appellant before us, the Tribunal stated a case and referred the following question of law to the High Court of Bombay

facts.text: Bombay HC answered question in negative.

anchor.surface_text: The result is that we must agree with the view taken by the Tribunal and we must answer the question submitted to us in the negative.

facts.text: Supreme Court granted special leave.

anchor.surface_text: After the decision of the High Court the appellant obtained special leave and has companye to us in pursuance of special leave granted by this Court.

facts.text: SC (Das J): HUF not resident; appeal dismissed.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are of the opinion that the High Court companyrectly answered the question, The appeal fails and is dismissed with companyts,

facts.text: Hidayatullah J dissent: HUF resident.

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment, the decision of the Bombay High Court, with respect, was erroneous. The answer to the question ought to have been in the affirmative.

facts.text: Tribunal found no partition; Nandlal remained coparcener.

anchor.surface_text: The Appellate Tribunal, Bombay, held that Nandlal was still a companyarcener and number a separated member, because the partition which was set up by him was number meant to be acted upon.
Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated February 16, 1955, of the Bombay High Court

issues.text: Whether the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal represented by Nandlal in the firm of Amulakh Amichand Co. of Bombay was resident in the taxable territories in the year of account relevant for the assessment year 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the Commissioner of Income- tax, Bombay, who is the appellant before us, the Tribunal stated a case and referred the following question of law to the High Court of Bombay for its decision under s. 66 1  of the Act. The question was in these terms Whether the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal represented by Nandlal in the firm of Amulakh Amichand Co. of Bombay was resident in the taxable territories in the year of account relevant for the assessment year 1945-46.

issues.text: Whether Nandlal represented the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal of Wadhwan in Saurashtra, in the firm Amulakh Amichand Co., Bombay, and later on in the firms Amulakh Amichand Co., Bombay and Banaras.

anchor.surface_text: Then, there -as an, appeal to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal, Bombay. Two questions were raised before the Tribunal Whether Nandlal represented the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal of Wadhwan number in Saurashtra, in the firm Amulakh Amichand Co., Bombay, and later on in the firms Amulakh Amichand Co., Bombay and Banaras.

issues.text: Whether the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal was resident in the taxable territories in the relevant years of account.

anchor.surface_text: Whether the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal was resident in the taxable territories in the relevant years of account. The Tribunal held on the first question that Nandlal and later Girdharlal joined the Bombay firm and also the Banaras firm of Amulakh Amichand Co. as representing the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal

issues.text: whether the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal was resident in the taxable territories in the relevant year so as to make the sum of Rs. 1,50,000 taxable under s. 4(1)(b)(iii) of the Act on the basis of such residence.

anchor.surface_text: We are companycerned with the second question, namely, whether the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal was resident in the taxable territories in the relevant year so as to make the sum of Rs. 1,50,000 taxable under s. 4  1   b   iii  of the Act on the basis of such residence.

issues.text: whether the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal could be said to be resident in the taxable territories i.e., British India in the relevant year under the provisions of s. 4A(b) of the Act, even though the family carried on its own cloth business wholly outside the taxable territories.

anchor.surface_text: We must, therefore, keep in mind the narrow scope of the question before us, which is whether the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal companyld be said to be resident in the taxable territories  i. e., British India  in the relevant year under the provisions of s. 4A b  of the Act, even though the family carried on its own cloth business wholly outside the taxable territories.

issues.text: does the existence of the said partnership establish the residence of the family?

anchor.surface_text: The point for decision, therefore, is does the existence of the said partnership establish the residence of the family ? This raises two questions before us firstly, whether the firm of Amulakh Amichand Co. is one of the affairs of the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal

issues.text: whether the firm of Amulakh Amichand Co. is one of the affairs of the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal because that is the only affair which has relation to the income sought to be taxed and on which the appellant relies for determining the residence of the family

anchor.surface_text: firstly, whether the firm of Amulakh Amichand Co. is one of the affairs of the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal because that is the only affair which has relation to the income sought to be taxed and on which the appellant relies for determining the residence of the family secondly, where the companytrol

issues.text: where the control and management of the said affair, looked at from the point of view of the Hindu undivided family, is situate.

anchor.surface_text: secondly, where the companytrol and management of the said affair, looked at from the point of view of the Hindu undivided family, is situate. We think that in the companytext of the facts found in the case, these two questions are interlinked.

issues.text: Is there any affair of the Hindu undivided family in the taxable territories in such circumstances?

anchor.surface_text: Two questions then arise, which are Is there any affair of the Hindu undivided family in the taxable territories in such circumstancesand Is the fact that the companyarcener companytrols and manages the partnership, wholly or partly, sufficient to enable one to say that the companytrol

issues.text: Is the fact that the coparcener controls and manages the partnership, wholly or partly, sufficient to enable one to say that the control and management of the family is located in the taxable territories?

anchor.surface_text: and Is the fact that the companyarcener companytrols and manages the partnership, wholly or partly, sufficient to enable one to say that the companytrol and management of the family is located in the taxable territories ? Now, it is settled law that a Hindu undivided family cannot be a partner under the law of Partnership.

anchor.surface_text: The burden was on the assessee to establish this, and we were not shown any evidence in this behalf. The question can be decided here also on the burden of proof alone

holdings.text: The High Court correctly answered the question in the negative: the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal was not resident in the taxable territories for the assessment year 1945-46.

anchor.surface_text: Therefore, we are of the opinion that the High Court correctly answered the question, The appeal fails and is dismissed with costs,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partnership business not an 'affair' of HUF under s.4A(b) as HUF cannot control or manage it; control by individual coparcener; applies precedents on de facto control and Hindu law on coparcener partnerships.

holdings.text: The partnership firm of Amulakh Amichand Co. is not an 'affair' of the Hindu undivided family capable of being controlled and managed by the HUF as such.

anchor.surface_text: The point for decision, therefore, is does the existence of the said partnership establish the residence of the family ? This raises two questions before us firstly, whether the firm of Amulakh Amichand Co. is one of the affairs of the Hindu undivided family of Gandalal

holdings.reasoning_summary: Affairs under s.4A(b) must be capable of control by HUF as such; coparcener partners individually under Partnership Act and Hindu law; HUF exercises no controlling power over partnership.

holdings.text: Control and management under s.4A(b) means de facto control and management (head and brain), not merely the right or power to control.

anchor.surface_text: The expression control and management under s. 4A b signifies controlling and directive power, the head and brain as it is sometimes called. Furthermore, it is settled, we think, that the expression control and management means de facto control

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows settled law and precedent (B.R. Naik v. CIT); applies to facts where HUF has no de facto control over partnership.

holdings.text: A coparcener (even Karta) entering partnership with strangers does so individually; partnership is contractual between coparcener and others, not HUF; HUF not partner.

anchor.surface_text: The position in Hindu law with regard to a coparcener, even when he is the Karta, entering into partnership 1 1950 S.C.R. 961. with others in carrying on a business is equally well settled. The partnership that is created is a contractual partnership

holdings.reasoning_summary: Well-settled Hindu law and Partnership Act; cites Kshetra Mohan; control lies with individual coparcener, not family.

holdings.text: If the Hindu undivided family itself carried on the business as its own, it would be an affair of the family under its control.

anchor.surface_text: We agree with the High Court that the position would be different if the Hindu undivided family itself carried on the business as its own business. In that case the business would be an affair of the family,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes direct HUF business (controllable affair) from coparcener's partnership (not controllable by HUF).

holdings.text: Place of accrual of income of HUF and place of its residence under s.4A(b) need not be the same; no paradox.

anchor.surface_text: At first sight it may appear paradoxical that the income from the two businesses at Bombay and Banaras in the hands of Nandlal and Girdharlal should be treated as income of the Hindu undivided family

holdings.reasoning_summary: Residence determined by control of affairs; income accrual separate; HUF income from partnership but no control over it.

holdings.text: The first question before Tribunal (whether Nandlal represented HUF in firm) does not fall for consideration; irrelevant for residence.

anchor.surface_text: We must make it clear at the very outset that the first question raised before the Tribunal and decided by it against the assessee does not fall for consideration. Whatever income Nandlal and Girdharlal received

holdings.reasoning_summary: Narrow scope: only residence for taxing remittance under s.4(1)(b)(iii); representation affects income status, not residence.

holdings.text: There was an affair of the HUF in taxable territories (coparceners' partnership activity); control and management partly therein makes resident.
holdings.reasoning_summary: From Hindu law perspective: communality, no individual share; partnership benefits family; coparceners' actions family affairs; even partial control suffices (textual 'wholly without').

holdings.text: Coparcener's partnership is affair of HUF under Hindu law (not Partnership law); control by coparceners in territories locates family control there.

anchor.surface_text: According to the true notion of an undivided family in Hindu law, no individual member of that family, whilst it remains undivided, can predicate of the joint and undivided property,

holdings.reasoning_summary: Three laws: Partnership (individual), Hindu (family benefit/common interest), IT (residence by control of income-related affairs); burden not discharged.

holdings.text: The answer to the question ought to have been in the affirmative: HUF resident.

anchor.surface_text: In my judgment, the decision of the Bombay High Court, with respect, was erroneous. The answer to the question ought to have been in the affirmative.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Partnership activity family undertaking; managed in territories by coparceners; de facto control not wholly outside.

precedents.citation: V. V. R. N. M. Subbayya Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: V. V. R. N. M. Subbayya Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 1 this Court held that the test for deciding the residence of a Hindu undivided family laid down in s. 4A b of the Act was based very largely on the rule which had been applied in England to cases of companyporations, and though numbermally a Hindu undivided family would be taken to be resident in British India

precedents.case_name: V. V. R. N. M. Subbayya Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: test for residence of Hindu undivided family under s. 4A(b) based on control and management of its affairs situated wholly without taxable territories; 'affairs' relevant to Income-tax Act and related to income; family may have multiple residences

precedents.citation: Kshetra Mohan Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax, West Bengal 1

anchor.surface_text: Kshetra Mohan Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax, West Bengal 1 . The companyarcener is undoubtedly accountable to the family for the income received, but the partnership is exclusively one between the companytracting members, including the individual companyarceners and the strangers to the family.

precedents.case_name: Kshetra Mohan Sannyasi Charan Sadhukhan v. Commissioner of Excess Profits Tax West Bengal
precedents.cited_proposition: partnership created by karta is contractual partnership governed by Indian Partnership Act 1932 between individual coparcener and other partners, not between family and others

precedents.citation: B. R. Naik v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1

anchor.surface_text: B. R. Naik v. Commissioner of Income-tax 1 . It is also -quite clear, we think, that if a companyarcener becomes a partner on behalf of the joint family with strangers in a firm which carries on business in the taxable territories, that by itself will number determine the residence of the family unless the companytrol and management of the firm is at least, in part, in the Hindu undivided family.

precedents.case_name: B. R. Naik v. Commissioner of Income-tax
precedents.cited_proposition: expression 'control and management' means de facto control and management and not merely the right or power to control and manage

precedents.citation: V. V. R. N. M. Subbayya Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2

anchor.surface_text: V. V. R. N. M. Subbayya Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax, Madras 2 proceeded on the basis of onus only and as was specifically stated therein, it was companyfined to the year of assessment to which the case related and it was left open to the appellant of that case to show in future years by proper evidence that the seat of companytrol and management of the affairs of the family was wholly outside British India.

precedents.case_name: V. V. R. N. M. Subbayya Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: decision proceeded on basis of onus of proof for exception under s.4A(b); left open for future years

precedents.citation: V. V. N. M. Subbayya Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income- tax, Madras 1

anchor.surface_text: V. V. N. M. Subbayya Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income- tax, Madras 1 , and pointed out that by the expression the affairs of the Hindu undivided family was meant number the private or domestic affairs of the family but some affairs, which had some reference to the Income-tax Act.

precedents.case_name: V. V. N. M. Subbayya Chettiar v. Commissioner of Income-tax Madras
precedents.cited_proposition: 'affairs of the Hindu undivided family' means affairs with reference to Income-tax Act, not private or domestic

precedents.citation: Charandas Haridas V. company-missioner of Income-tax, Bombay 2

anchor.surface_text: Charandas Haridas V. company-missioner of Income-tax, Bombay 2 that in such a situation the matter has to be looked at in the light of three separate and independent branches of law. They are the law of Partnership, the Hindu law and the law relating to Income-tax.

precedents.case_name: Charandas Haridas v. Commissioner of Income-tax Bombay
precedents.cited_proposition: position of coparcener joining partnership with strangers viewed through law of partnership, Hindu law, and income-tax law separately

anchor.surface_text: Appovier v. Rama Subba Aiyan which reads According to the true numberion of an undivided family in Hindu law, numberindividual member of that family, whilst it remains undivided, can predicate of the joint and undivided property, that he, that particular member, has a certain definite share . The proceeds of undivided property must be brought, according to the theory of an undivided family, to the companymon chest or purse, and then dealt with according to the modes of enjoyment by the members of an undivided family.

precedents.cited_proposition: no individual member of undivided Hindu family can claim definite share in joint property; proceeds to common chest
precedents.cited_holding: According to the true notion of an undivided family in Hindu law, no individual member... has a certain definite share.

precedents.citation: Katama Natchiar v. Rajah of Shivaganga 2

anchor.surface_text: Katama Natchiar v. Rajah of Shivaganga 2 in the following words There is companymunity of interest and unity of possession between all the members of the family, and upon the death of any one of them the others may well take by survivorship that in which they had during the deceaseds life-time a companymon interest and a companymon possession.

precedents.case_name: Katama Natchiar v. Rajah of Shivaganga
precedents.cited_proposition: community of interest and unity of possession among members of undivided family; survivorship
precedents.cited_holding: There is community of interest and unity of possession between all the members of the family...
